title: Fundamental Survey on Neuromorphic Based Audio Classification
author: Amlan Basu (Neuromorphic Sensor Signal Processing Lab, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, U.K.), Pranav Chaudhari, Gaetano Di Caterina, ...
relevance_why: This survey reviews neuromorphic computing approaches like Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs), which could enhance audio classification mechanisms in Haohe Liu's audio processing work, particularly in applications requiring real-time analysis and efficiency.
background: Neuromorphic systems leverage brain-inspired architectures to facilitate efficient audio classification by mimicking biological neural networks.
contribution: This survey introduces the current state-of-the-art in neuromorphic audio classification to solve the limitations of traditional methods, achieving insights into various techniques and hardware advancements.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional methods in audio classification rely on complex algorithms and manually crafted features, struggling with energy efficiency and robustness.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work emphasizes neuromorphic approaches that utilize asynchronous spike-based computation, improving energy consumption and real-time performance.

key_innovation: Focuses on Spiking Neural Networks and neuromorphic hardware to provide efficient solutions for audio classification, integrating both event-driven processing and bio-inspired learning methods.
real_world_impact: The findings can facilitate advancements in audio classification tasks for applications in healthcare monitoring, surveillance, and environmental analysis.
limitations: The survey does not specify any limitations of the discussed methods, focusing mainly on their advantages.

new_terms.Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs): **Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs)** are a class of artificial neural networks that closely mimic the temporal dynamics of biological neurons, transmitting information via discrete events called spikes.
new_terms.neuromorphic computing: **Neuromorphic computing** refers to computing systems that are designed to emulate the structure and functioning of biological neural networks to enhance processing efficiency and adaptability.
